resources.string: The mission of the Department of Computer Science and Information Systems at SVSU is to provide an outstanding education to its students in accordance with the guidelines of the SVSU mission, to advance scholarship in the key domains of the computing and information systems sciences, and to engage in activities that improve the welfare of society and enhance the reputation of SVSU.
An * indicates an elective class, A CIS student is required to take 12 credits, while a CS student is required to take 8 credits. The year it is placed in is only a recommendation.
A ^ indicates a CIS business requirement. It can be swapped out with ACCT 213 ECON 221, LAW 308, MGT 321 or MKT 331.

George Corser is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science and Information Systems (CSIS) at Saginaw Valley State University (SVSU). His research defines and analyzes location privacy and security protocols in vehicle networks. His teaching explores web and mobile app development, theoretical computer science and cybercrime. His professional service includes advisory and leadership positions in SVSU student organizations, international technical societies, and a cybercrime analysis consortium.

Il-Hyung Cho is an associate professor and chair of the Department of Computer Science at Saginaw Valley State University, Michigan, where he has been since 2003. During 2010-2011 he was a Visiting Professor of Bioinformatics lab at Washington State University. He received a B.E. in Electronic and Computer Engineering from Yonsei University in 1987, and an M.S. in Computer Science from Bowling Green State University. He received his Ph.D. in Computer Science from Clemson University in 2000. He worked at Iona Technologies in Boston as a software engineer in 2000-2001, and at Clemson University as visiting lecturer in 2001-2003.

I graduated with PhD in Computational Analysis and Modeling (2013) from Louisiana Tech University, Ruston, USA. Prior that, I received MS and BSc in Computer Science and Engineering from University of Dhaka, Bangladesh in 2008 and 2006 respectively. I received MS in Mathematics (2011) and MS in Computer Science (2013) from Louisiana Tech University. Before joining SVSU in 2013, I was a research assistant from March, 2009 to February, 2013 at Centr for Secure Cyberspace at Louisiana Tech University. My research interests include detecting and mitigating cyber-behavioral anomalies, behavioral biometrics, machine learning, knowledge discovery from data, image processing and human activity detection from video. I am a member of IEEE and ACM.

Computer Science deals with why computer systems works. This path will offer more programming and development opportunities. The Computer Information Systems deals with how computer systems work. This is more the management side of the IT spectrum, dealing with databases and networking.
Both CIS and CS students will need a combined base of math, ethics and computer programming basics. The shared courses are MATH 103, CS105, CS 116, CS215, COM105, and PHIL205A/210B
